column4: The Eskimo museum is an excellent collection of history and culture of the Churchill area. One can spend a lot of time examining the numerous sculptures and learning the stories behind some of them. There is also a huge stuffed polar bear and walrus, among the displays. The museum has a small, but very nice gift shop..
Small museum dealing with Inuit culture. Well organized displays that let you learn about the culture through works of art. Interesting carvings and good audio commentary for independent travelers.
Great place full of history and we'll worth a visit when in Churchill. Great little gift shop also, great books and gifts for people back home.
Really enjoyed not only the handmade displays but also the incredible animals, tools and means of transportation. Well worth the time

You can find the most interesting stuffed animals and remains as well as miniature carvings. It is the best place to find Inuit art for sale. a good selection of soap stone carvings as well as prints and postcards.

An easy way to spend a couple of hours in Churchill. Lots of exhibits and history with quite a few audio explanations. I enjoyed listening to the info on the artifacts and looking at the stuffed animals. A really neat place that has a great deal to iffer
This is the type of museum that really helps you understand the history of the area and the native peoples. If you have an extra hour in Churchill, this is a must see.
A fascinating museum with a local expert on hand to talk you through the numerous displays. There is also a interesting shop selling a wide range of books and souvenirs there too.
A must visit place...traces history through a nassive, impressive collection of native arts and artifacts. Very sharing, knowledgeable curator and staff.
Amazing carvings and helpful staff... great place for souvenirs. Highly recommend visiting here! Outstanding

Everything you could possible want to know about Inuit people, the Itsanitaq Museum. Amazing artifacts, carvings, jewelry, tools, paintings, displays, and a great curator, Lorraine. She knows everything about the First People. It's a small place but full of items with a small sovign

This was a very thorough exhibit of Eskimo cuture and art. Many items in the gift shop were Canadian-made. There's a full-size birch bark canoe! There were many taxidermied specimens of the Arctic as well. The tiny Eskimo carvings were interesting as well as almost hard to see!
If you go to Churchill you must take the time to see the Eskimo museum. It is fantastic. The number of pieces and the self guided tour aids were fascinating.
This was a very interesting museum, so much to look at. It also had the best gift shop in Churchill. I bought my souvenirs and little gifts there on my last day.
A small but compacted history of Churchill. Proceeds from the sale from the gift shop go directly into maintaining and improving the museum
Well curated, and our guide was very informative. The carvings and art work are amazing. It is a brief touch with a culture that is much ignored.

This small but excellent museum is a must see on your trip to Chirchill. It is very well done and treats all subjects In an honest and respectful manner. The history is so well explained visually and verbally that it leaves you wanting more. The artifacts that have been recovered are amazing and well perserved.
This is worth a stop to get a tour of the wealth of material that is a relatively small facility. I learned a lot about the history of the area, in particular about the native peoples.
Wonderful little museum. Excellent collection of Inuit artifacts. The gift shop has a ton of books, Inuit art, and many other items. Reasonable prices, and the proceeds stay in the area

Definitely the one place you have to visit while in Churchill. The artifacts were amazing and so many of them for such a small place. I learned a lot about the Inuit and the history of the area. The curators there were fabulous and knowledgable, and they have the best gift shop in town.
A one room museum that was full of really interesting First Nation displays and a great gift shop. Our docent was knowledgable, and thankfully didn't go on and on. A enjoyable 45 minute visit.
As others have said, it is a small museum. It is helpful to have a volunteer explain the artifacts so you understand what it is you are looking at. A lot of information is crammed into a small space.
Yoh can pet a polar bear here as well as learn about the people and the animals of the arctic. You can feel the various hides of the various animals. Simple but engaging exhibits

This is a one room museum absolutely packed with a zillion beautiful and interesting pieces of art of local First Nation artists old and new. Really fascinating- a must if you are at all interested in native culture. And a tiny alcove with wonderful gifts to take home. I bought books for children, beautiful pewter ornaments, a magnet and charms...
exhibits from the area and the culture. You can spend 30 minutes here and the staff are helpful. Reasonably good gift shop
Free. Very friendly and knowledgeable museum employees. Lots to see in one large room. Narwhale tusks, musk ox polar bear and lots of carvings from locals

This museum houses many Inuit artifacts. Viewing them is awesome to see the creativity of the people of the Arctic. The staff are very knowledgeable and really bring the exhibits and artifacts to life.
A way to get insight into the First nation and Inuit people. Again, knowledgeable staff and a nice tour.....

This one-room museum contains artifacts from Inuit, Metis and others who've lived in the Churchill area over the years. Intricate carvings from bone, tusk and stone tell the story of survival and creativity in a harsh yet beautiful and bountiful environment. You can take a quick look or spend a few hours reading the provenance on items in the collection....

Anyone visiting Churchill should visit this museum. Main item here is Inuit carving of many varieties and media. Space is limited, but written interpretation is minimal and could/should be expanded if possible. There is perhaps too much on display? If you are really interested, try to get a tour of the museum from the curator, if possible, for better interpretation....

This is a well planned, relatively small museum showing primarily eskimo sculpture. Most of the works are contemporary and not of the quality of earlier work. It is an enjoyable hour or so visit and it is possible to buy some Inuit sculpture. Given the few things to do in Churchill, this is worth your time

The Eskimo museum is a small single room with a stuffed polar bear, walrus, and a musk ox. There are a couple Inuit canoes and then lots of small handicrafts in glass cases. Not interactive or engaging. Not a place for kids or teenagers. Free. Has a tiny store within the room that sells $5 polar bear bottle openers and...
The museum isn't very big but it has a good variety of animals and things to look at. There is also a nice little souvenir shop section which has some lovely books and collectibles.
This museum is definitely worthwhile a visit and tells you a lot about the Eskimo culture and life, polar bears, whales, etc

it was a good introduction given ba local person, i would have appreciated a longer one though,very nice merchandizingvery interesting insight o into local culture but it would take more than one hour to understand all , more like three hours event though it is only one room !!definitely worth going !
The docent are super knowledgeable and helpful. There is LOTS packed in to a single room and worth a visit to see lots of Inuit & Arctic artifacts.

The museum, which is now called Itsanitaq, houses a collection of Inuit art and other artifacts. The stuffed animals are the first thing to draw your eye but it is worth it to spend your time going around the perimeter of the building to look at all the art. It is one of the finest collections of Inuit art outside...
Nice place to visit if you got some free time while in Churchill. They have fairly large collection of items on display as well as a souvenir shop.
Fantastic display of art and historical items. Great taxidermed animals, including an enormous walrus head and polar bear. Nice little gift shop also.
Well done exhibits are very interesting. It has a huge collection of native art including carvings and scrimshaw. We also did some shopping in the reasonably priced gift shop.
If you our intersted in culture and history this is a must see ! Souvenirs and handcrafted sculptures reasonably priced !

Deep knowledge and experience of the northern culture's survival and enjoyment of their unique environment have a good representation in this collection. The artifacts and artworks of past and present combine to give a learning environment for those interested in the several native cultures, and the effects of European influence.
This museum looks small from the outside but it has a large collection of items to see and lots to learn about.

There are countless pieces of art and artifacts in this seemingly small museum, as well as impressive wildlife specimens, kayaks, etc. Some of the artifacts are thousands of years old. The Inuit legends/stories dispersed amongst the exhibits (or explaining them) are fascinating and unique. Want to know where narwhals come from (deceptive mothers), or why you should not marry an...
great to see and hear the report of many artifacts depicting life for first Nations people who live(d) in the North.
Very informative and lots to learn about their way of life. The staff were friendly and very helpful.
Beautiful art! You do not want to miss this museum!They have some pieces for sale, which I found very fairly priced!Wish I could have bought more! Very friendly staff!

A very interesting little museum. The staff is very friendly ,the displays tell the story of the area & they have the very best prices in town in their gift area---be sure you ask about their hours before you head over---not far from the Bay views....

The museum is small but there was a lot to see if you like native art. There are shelves full of carvings depicting scenes such as hunting, dog sledding, fishing, igloo buiding. There are also examples of native gear and some stuffed examples of the local wildlife. The gift shop had a large selection of carvings for sale as well.

It's a small but detailed exhibit with many artefacts and artworks. Definitely worth a visit for a half hour or hour. My favourite piece was the narwhale skull with two tusks! There's a donation box inside, a few dollars is recommended but I bought a few items from the gift shop instead.
Interesting exhibits and wonderful carvings to share. Would recommend to anyone visiting Churchill. They are currently rebranding the name

The museum is a great little place to stop and have a look around. It's got interesting history of the people, traditional carvings and even a full sized Polar Bear, Fox and Walrus amongst other things. It's also a little gift shop with lots of books (for all ages), jewelry, mugs, post cards, t-shirts etc. If you're in town and...
It's full of native artifacts and info. It's not huge, so you can do it in about an hour. We bought a nice stone carving. It's a must see. Listen to the phone recordings. You'll see.
Excellent displays and explanations and a grand selection of books and gifts. Easy to walk to from any hotel.
I just returned from my third trip to Churchill and every time I am there, I make sure to stop in at this fantastic museum. I would recommend that all travels stop there for a visit.

It doesn't have the interior appeal of more modern museums but there is A LOT in this place. It's stunning. There is also a really good gift shop with local jams from the wild berries that grow there. The carvings are beautiful. It's super cool in it's kitchy-ness. There are audio phones to listen to at the different displays. Also...
Excellent museum with loads of artifacts and stuffed animals! We spent a fair bit of time wandering around the museum...it's free too!

The museum was small and many of the displays were interesting but it has no wheelchair ramp so we had to carry up my son and his chair up four or five steps. Lots of the display cases were to high to see if sitting and the staff did not even acknowledge our existence the entire time there.

The Eskimo Museum should be on everyone's Churchill itinerary. It displays an overwhelming number of carvings and drums, plus narwhal tusks, traditional kayaks, and iconic arctic animals (taxidermied). I just wish that the interpretation of all these amazing artifacts was a bit better. The cases are dated, though functional. I understand that if labels were used, the museum would need...
The Eskimo museum is very interesting. Lots of carvings with descriptions. The kayaks were amazing. The museum curator was very well informed and helpful.
Located just off Hudson Bay beach area, features soapstone carvings, implements and stuffed mammals from around the area. No charge upon entry with a small gift shop to pick up souvenirs.
A very interesting museum in the middle of churchill. So many artifacts, useful information and a well stocked shop. Good way to spend a wet afternoon.
Amazing collection of art and history. Gift shop and great books and other souvenirs. You could walk through it very quickly, but could also spend a lot of time and learn a lot.

This has to be the most unique place I have ever visited . A buddy and I were walking around Churchill when he said we should go to the museum ,I thought why not. The place is not that big but holds years of unbelievable history. A kayak sewn so tightly it doesn't leak . A tiny carved dog team...
A small, local museum that has an impressive collection of native artifacts. Really beautiful carvings and authentic handiwork. Cheerful and knowledgeable staff. Definitely worth stopping in!

Located right in the center of the tiny town of Churchill, this museum is a must-visit. It teaches about the history of various First Peoples groups and the natural wonders of the Arctic. While it is small, there is truly something for everyone. I visited at least 4 times and saw something new each day. Also for those on a...
This is another unique site in Churchill. So many artifacts to view from the Northern people. I spent several hours there just to see everything. Definitely worth a visit.
This is a great place to visit between tours. The range of sculptures and history is amazing. The gift store has great books and gifts. I think it is a must see when in Churchill.

This museum was absolutely amazing. Highly recommend it and it's free. The wild life and history was incredible. I bought the book Churchill Hudson Bay a guide. To natural and cultural history and was lucky enough to have the author sign it
This is a small museum of native art. The docent is very knowledgeable and eager to explain the pieces. There is over 1000 pieces of native carvings collected by a priest over a 50 year period.

The museum is a great place to visit. It is free but we left a donation as it keeps the place running.There were many wonderful carvings lining the walls. We enjoyed seeing the animals that were mounted. The artic wolf is just huge! A real treat was seeing the kayaks made of skin. The skill involved in making them...
This is another good places to visit it show the art that the people made about the people and the animals

We had been told to visit the Eskimo Museum and patiently waited for its 1pm opening no Monday (it’s closed Sunday); and we are glad we didn’t miss out. This is almost as much an art gallery as it is a museum; one large room filled with Eskimo carvings, artifacts, animal hides and pictures. There is so much to look...

My mom and I made a point of stopping in here while we were in Churchill, on several recommendations. I highly recommend using the listening devices to explain/explore the artwork. It's stunning work on it's own, but when you know the meaning and history behind some of the pieces, it is even more so.

In a town of fewer than 1,000 residents, it's amazing to come across a museum that wouldn't be out of place in a major Canadian city. The Eskimo Museum concentrates on the history and culture of the Inuit from Nunavut and generally the eastern part of Canada's north. The historic exhibits date back more than 600 years with items like...

This museum, a small building in a small town rivals many other larger museums I've been in. I loved it. The docent/saleswoman/ticket seller had a phenomenal recall of the history and culture of the Eskimos.

Overall a very pleasant experience. Many beautiful examples of Inuit art. Particularly liked the ivory carving work. Had a chance to speak with the curator, she is very knowledgeable and friendly. If you're in Churchill I recommend this for a look into past cultures.
Interesting carvings and native lore attached to them. They also have Amundsen's chair from one of his ships. Good books and gifts.
A wide variety of elements; biofacts, photos, carvings, artworks with concise interpretive information.
A great museum to learn about Inuit life in the north and lots of artifacts to look at. Also several stations have audio description of items on display, very helpful.

For a small museum it's filled with the most amazing Northern Canadian artifacts dating back to the 1600's and earlier. The collection is so well curated that it's easy to spend a couple of hours getting lost in time. There is an incredible Gift Shop at the back of the museum that we wished we had been able to spend...
Excellent! I highly recommend it. Very inexpensive like 2 or 3 $. Our tour took us, but right in town, near library. Can easily do on your own.
Its a nice place which shows about the history of Churchill how people used to hunt for survival, their weapons and clothes are displayed.
I visited with a tour group. The staff was very attentive to our questions and gave excellent history of the Churchill area and the items in the museum. They have one of the best gift shops in town.
A great place to go and see the different Eskimo carvings and history of Churchill. A great place to spend an hour or so reading and viewing everything about Churchill and area.

Visited as part of a tour group visit, a member of staff did a brief input regarding the way of life of the First Nations, it was quite interesting.It has small displays of carvings and artwork of the First Nations/inuits.A small shop with trinkets, t shirts, some of the polar bear stone carvings were expensive, but not carved...
This is a must do in Churchill. You learn a lot about the resources available to those who live in the region. Amazing craftwork. Good place for memento shopping as well

The visit to the Eskimo Museum was a great way to understand the local culture and to learn the history of Churchill. Apart from the great exhibits, the museum has a small store where you can buy souvenirs as well.
I was blown away by the extent of artifacts at the museum.. wonderful carvings, and loads of history for a small museum.. a must see while in Churchill

Impressive collection of art and artifacts. Great canoes and stuffed animals to help visitors understand more of the local ecology. Beautiful carving and terrific gift shop. The tour guide was very informative. Don't miss a visit to the Eskimo Museum.
The art is sublime! The bookstore is the best in town. Talk to the curator: she is vey knowledgeable. Take your time and remain open to the beauty of every single piece.

As you know there is limited option in Churchill as place to visit but was glad to visit this museum and was really interesting. They had also a couple of souvenir that you could buy (different from the other shops).

We only had a few minutes at this museum because of the incredibly busy schedule we had on our tour. I've been to a number of museums and exhibits of Inuit art and this is one of the best. It was also recommended to us to purchase authentic crafts and it did not disappoint.

I visited the Eskimo museum recently whilst in Churchill however I wouldn't recommend it. The museum was laid out in a really strange manner and the exhibits didn't have a lot of commentary and I questioned the relevance. The staff were lovely though and it was more interesting engaging them in conversation.

Oh, the history of the Churchill Area. It is all here in this small but thorough museum. The staff are incredible - several books have been authored by the staff and available in the gift shop. Take lots of time - it is free - and plan on several visits. A great place to buy those trinkets to remind you...
It is a small museum, but has a wealth of history. The guides are very helpful. It also has a small gift shop with a wonderful book selection
The museum is very well done with wonderful collections depicting the early life in the frozen tundra!

This museum is small but you could learn a lot. Those carvings are beautiful. The gift shop provides the best price in the town. The price of the same postcard I bought from hotel is only $1 here while $1.25 in the hotel.
Full of interesting First People sculptures and history with a curator who can tell you even more. Very good shopping if you are looking for Inuit sculptures as well as other things.
This is a great little museum, chock full of artifacts. Would have liked to have spent more time there. Also interesting selection of books on sale!

I learned a lot from the Eskimo Museum. The carvings were beautiful and the other artifacts were so well-preserved one could be forgiven for thinking they were props. You can learn a lot about the lives and challenges of the northern people here, especially with a guide. The technology (telephone handsets) is a little outdated, but mostly functional. It would...

I was in Churchill for polar bear season and during some downtime our guide took our group to see this museum. I was surprised by some of the impressive exhibits. Things you're not going to see often, like hide canoes, a stuffed walrus and giant narwhal tusks. Definitely worth checking out.

We were fortunate to have museum curator Lorraine Brandson to introduce us this more than 70 years old establishment. This museum is mainly for Inuit art and culture, but also includes some archaeological materials and eye-catching natural specimens in northern region, such as stuffed polar bear, musk ox and so forth. You can also find original hide-covered kayaks and even...
The museum gives insight into the struggles of living in an area without amenities and harsh weather.
The staff was very educated and excited to share their knowledge. They have a nice selection of books and souvenirs.
Very informative small museum. The tour guide at the museum was very good and could answer all questions asked. Had small gift shop . Well worth the visit
Spent some time at the museum and listened to the curator talk about the exhibits in relation to the relevant history. Very interesting things to observe

The Eskimo museum is mainly a place where you can look at different sculptures that give insights into the life of the Inuit people. It does not look much and it is only one hall, but there are over 4000 pieces located in it and it is a fantastic place to spend your time. I guess if you are really...
Well worth visiting. Displays are well done and very interesting. Small gift shop area has some nice things done locally.
While walking round town we popped in here for a look. While small there is plenty of interesting things to look at for both adults and kids. Some nice local takeaways too.

I'm not really a museum guy, but this museum has an extensive selection of Inuit art and artifacts, a huge stuffed polar bar, vintage watercraft and probably the best gift shop in town. Staff are very friendly and helpful and this museum affords the greatest opportunity to spend the most time at any single location in town.
Some really interesting artifacts and stories about wildlife and aboriginal life in the North.Definitely recommended a visit if you're in Churchill!
Upon walking in the door - we were in awe at the level and quality of the exhibits. Souvenir shop was among the best in Churchill.

This is a small museum, but it's packed with Inuit art and other attractions such as narwhal tusks, kayaks, a stuffed polar bear, walrus and a musk ox. But most importantly, it has the best gift shop in town, with the most reasonable prices!

What a neat place!! They have soo many different things to see. There are a lot of beautiful pieces of artwork made of ivory. They have one with a polar bear using a boulder to take out a walrus. They can,t use their teeth or claws to kill one for food, they have too much fat. I just learned a...

The museum is great for anyone who likes to study artefacts in detail. You could spend a lot of time there. For me, there were many similarities among the items This made it somewhat repetitive. I would still strongly recommend a visit. It has an excellent collection of books available for purchase - the best in Churchill.

What a wonderful museum. Vintage, contemporary, and old artifacts of Native persons are all collected and displayed well. There Are a few taxidermy exhibits that are interesting. The walk up the hill is worth it. A must do in Churchill.
This museum is loaded in art and information. Allow yourself at least an hour to really take it all in!!
Lots of old artifacts that depict the life of people who lived in the North long before European settlement; one of a kind.

This museum has an incredible collection of Inuit art, especially sculpture. Some pieces are over 50 years old and exhibit impressive craftsmanship. I visited twice so I could go back and revisit my favorite pieces. Hours are limited so be sure to plan around this when you visit Churchill! A much better collection of Inuit art than I saw in...

For a small museum, it has it all. I found the recorded commentary very interesting and easy to follow. The carvings are incredible. There are guides that can take you around the museum, but I toured it on my own. There is no cost to view the museum but a donation can be made. You should allow at least an...

Very small museum, basically one room; however, there are extremely interesting artifacts on display. There are telephones with oral explanations of what you are seeing. There is also a small display of things to purchase, including books.

Free. Spend minimum of 1 hour. Lots of interesting displays from geology to fossils to taxidermy figures to tools of the Inuit. Also least expensive souvenirs we found.Post Office across from Eskimo Museum will stamp “Polar Bear” in passport.
Very interesting display of a number of local tribes. Well laid out, easy to reach and walk through. Small, though.
Amazing local museum - art from all the North - not just Churchill.Beautifully displayed. Small gift shop. Friendly staff. A must see in Churchill.

The collection of cultural artifacts and wildlife exhibits are wonderful. There is also a very nice little gift shop with a fantastic selection of books, in addition to the usual tourist gifts and clothing. If you have any appreciation for Inuit culture and/or wildlife, this is a great little museum. It is free but there is a donation box...be sure...
There is so much to see in this little museum we went back for a second visit! I enjoyed the audio interpretations of the exhibits. A definite must see while visiting Churchill!
Very interesting place. Amanda does a great presentation. Great little gift shop with local carvings and Canadian made tea towels, etc.Staff are very kind and informative.

Pretty much everyone who visits Churchill will end up at the Eskimo Museum sooner or later. It's located right in town, and it's free (donations accepted).The museum does a good job of explaining the people of the north, primarily through their artwork. There are audio stations throughout the museum that give good explanations of the artifacts and what they...

In addition to having many interesting museum pieces, they have some very nice Inuit art. Some of the larger displays could have had better written explanations.A very nice exhibit.It seems that a small entrance fee may help them financially. I observed very few offering a donation.

You pretty much have to go here if you're visiting Churchill for a couple days or more. There are a good many interesting things to see, and they clearly have the best carvings at the best prices in town, and a good collection of books for sale.
A small museum with small carved pieces. Some interesting. Limited hours. Since there is close to nothing to do while in Churchill it is worth a visit.
By far one of the most interesting museums I've been too, you need to study the artefact's and listen to the recordings. Great clothing store with some unique items.

My Mom and I love this museum. It's filled ceiling to floor with fantastic Inuit sculptures, photos of Inuit life and excellent samples of stuffed arctic wildlife. It's easy to spend hours in there and then notice more just as you're leaving! A lovely young woman who was hired to log new art pieces gave us a little tour pointing...
well staffed - well organized - wealth of info from and about Inuit and arctic survival. free quiet- worth the visit.
This is one of Churchill's best kept secrets! Beautiful museum and really nice gift shop! I went back twice.
We had a very interesting evening here learning about the Eskimo culture. The displays were informative and varied

First Nations, or Inuit is preferred instead of Eskimo which means "eaters of raw meat" is one of the first things that I learned. A very informative and friendly museum guide will be able to handle your questions and comments. Authentic displays present the lifestyle of the First Nations of Canada.

A small, free museum packed with items native to the area or culture. We had only 20 minutes due to very windy weather that plummeted the temperatures. I snapped pictures of what peeked my interest immediately, so I could study them later. Helpful sales staff in the gift shop and 2 clean bathrooms. A highlight of Churchill and well worth...

The museum is free but they have a very good collection of artifacts. I have been there about 3-4 times over the years but I was there in 02/2015. Afterwards, you can spend some money on books, shirts, t-shirt and other stuff.The lady was extremely nice to me as I showed up before opening hours and had let me...
This is a very small museum. You need an hour at most. It has some very interesting exhibits and examples of First Nation and Inuit artwork and artifacts.
This was a small museum with interesting exhibits and it was free. The lady working there was very helpful with any questions. There was also a gift shop inside this place.
Great gift shop - one of the very few places to buy souvenirs and post cards. Don't miss the post office across the street - they will stamp "polar bear" on your passport.
Very interesting insight into Inuit culture with some great exhibits and artefacts. Just a ten minute walk from the Lazy Bear Lodge.

It was a very interesting museum and we seem to browse through it for ages. Enjoyed it very much. We didn't have much of an idea of the history of the Eskimos but after our time spent there and the books we purchased we have a greater knowledge.

When staying in Churchill, this museum is a must-see. Although the museum is in a single room, it is surprisingly packed with exhibits and has enthusiastic, well informed staff, who are happy to answer questions. It also has a small, but very nice, shop in the corner of the room.
Mostly inuit art is visualized in this museum. Worth to go and also have a look at the tourist gift shop
Small, but packed with good stuff and great staff. We returned for a second visit and to buy books for the train to Winnipeg
very informative on Eskimo life- very good art work- nice small gifts to purchase including some videos of what I saw...
Fascinating old artifacts, knowledgeable staff, most interesting of all is that it is funded by the catholic church.
The museum did a good job of giving an overview of the area and the people. Great break from riding around the tundra. Friendly staff.

It's small, just one large room. But you get a good feel for the very different place you are visiting. Lots of Inuit art and handicrafts, some very good explanations of native lifestyles, a small gift and book shop. I was particularly impressed with the seal hunting display.

Curators and docents are pleasant and know their artifacts. Photographs are allowed and please, do take time to really LOOK at the high quality work that the Inuit artisans created. Fun hunt: find what is wrong with the polar bear on exhibit-the staff knows the answer and I'm not going to give away the answer! The gift shop manages to...
This little museum is run by the Catholic Church and is an extraordinarily good collection of local arts, artefacts and creatures. Recommend leaving yourself a good amount of time to browse.
The art is recently made but in the traditional way by the Inuit people. The curator was great she knew the history. Proceeds go to the comunity
Very small museum but fun to go through. You are allowed to take photographs. The small gift shop had nice children's books.
There is an amazing amount of artifacts in this little museum as well as a great little gift store. Do not miss it!
This is a small museum but worth your time to visit. The guide was very knowledgeable and personable. they have some very nice art pieces and t-shirts.
This Museum is a gem in this little town of Churchill. It's very Interesting to see how the Eskimo people lived.and is a Must See! Very nice indeed.
Interesting little museum, but most note-worthy for its gift shop. Our group did more shopping there than any place else in town.
During some down time in Churchill, we stopped into the museum. There is large amount of artifacts and information on display here and is well worth the time to inspect.
small and No charge to visit, and some cute children's books and other nice gift items for purchase.
Excellent organization and artifacts. Sculptures were particularly good. I have to add more to reach my quota.

A great opportunity to learn and understand the native people and their culture. Wonderful display of artifacts, and a good selection of books for adults and children about the area; the people and nature.
fab little museum re all things eskimo - some great art pieces - good for 45 minutes browse when in churchill

I watched the unique displayed items there during my limited time of my arrival day in Churchill. The stone carvings were marvellous but those avaialble for purchase tended to be very expensive and so I decided to buy none with some regret.

This is a free museum and well worth a couple of hours, lots of artifacts and displays from the First Nation peoples. Really gives you a perspective on how brutal the sub tundra climate is and what it takes to survive there

Although the museum is relatively small, it is packed full of very interesting things. I particularly liked the miniature set of carved tools. There were also some lovely little sculptures. As you enter the museum you are greeted by the sight of a stuffed polar bear in a glass case, and behind that a stuffed musk ox. There is a...

Here we learned about how the natives lived long ago, how they lived off the land and the importance of nature that is still being taught today. How they used the pelts to keep warm; the meat of animals and birds to feed their families and the respect they have for all living creatures.
This is a small well laid out museum with some interesting artefacts, but won't take long to see everything!

You'll need around an hour or so to browse through all of the curious and interesting pieces on display at the Eskimo Museum. The only real draw back to this place is its' archaic name, which is immediately offensive due to the obvious racial slur. The staff at the museum were helpful, welcoming and kind. It's a great place to...
Definitely worth a visit, I thought this was a really cool museum, very interesting. It only takes about an hour to go through then there is a really nice gift shop .
I am not a museum person, but this place was so interesting. Lots to see and take in. It was interesting to see the different animals, artifacts and art.
This was a great place to visit in Churchill, lots of history and artwork, also with a great gift shop.

There is a great deal of information here as well as an enthusiastic person to take you through with explanations, if you wish. The souvenirs for sale, including a large selection of books, seems to be about the best selection in town
Loved the beautiful arts of the North. Would have been good to have local indigenous person at the desk.
Brilliant! We really enjoyed the museum. We went in because our tour was cancelled because of bad weather. We thought the exhibits were awesome
It was a good place to go and see some of the artwork and shop at the gift shop. Some of the carvings were pretty neat to see.
Numerous artifacts and taxidermy specimens throughout the museum. Very helpful and knowledgeable staff. The gift shop had a wide variety of souvenirs at the most reasonable prices we found.

Similar to the Skógar Folk Museum in Iceland this single roomed hall is crammed with artifacts and sculptures and taxidermy specimens, nearly everything meticulously labelled with information. This might excite some people but overwhelms me.I like museum exhibitions that either display a narrative or timeline or group objects into themes and this has yet to be applied to the...
Lots of carvings and artefacts. We liked the kayaks and learning about how the Inuits lived. There is a gift shop which has a lot of books about polar bears, northern lights and Inuit life

The Eskimo Museum has a lot of intersting artifacts that depict the life of the people in the Arctic. This is a worthwhile place to visit to get an understanding of the area. The ladies at the musuem are wonderful & there are a lot of great souvenirs.

Fabulous museum, with more information than you can absorb in a brief visit. Plan to spend at least one hour, and have one of the docents take you around the museum if you possibly can. Oh, and the gift shop here is the best in town! Plan to shop! :D

Its a small exhibit, which on first view appears to be awkwardly filled with quite recently sculpted Inuit-art. On a deeper view - and after looking at the true ancient Inuit-artifacts and -jewelery - it becomes clear, that all these sculptures and their displays do give interesting and first hand insight into Inuit-live (Who thought of the problems relieving oneself...

What a great little gem. I was surprised how much interesting stuff there was there. All kinds of artwork. History of Churchill. Just a little bit of everything. And we were the only ones there. Nevertheless, the museum has very convenient hours.

Churchill, Manitoba is a very tiny place on the shore of Hudson Bay. Although it is best known for viewing polar bears, it has a lot to offer about native culture. The Churchill Eskimo Museam represents this very well. It was -40 outside but warm and filled with interresting objects inside.Though only one large room, it is full of beautiful...

This is a true gem of the north - there's so much to see, and the staff are very informative. I've been many times, and never get sick of my time here. The gift shop is great, and has very fair prices! This is a must visit in Churchill.
Great museum to learn about the local history and talk to e local people. Excellent books and souvenirs to purchase too. Had a good couple of hours here.

This is essentially one large room filled with thousands of Inuit carvings, life-sized animal displays, fossils, kayaks and pictures. You could easily spend hours here if you went through in detail but you can get the highlights in a 40 minute visit. There is a gift shop that offers a variety of books (including beautifully illustrated children's books) and authentic...
Many interesting pieces of carved walrus ivory and whale and caribou bone. It also has a gift shop with many interesting books and pieces for purchase.

Really nice displays of carved Native art in bone and stone. Saw some fantastic carvings and the gift shop is really well-priced.Recommended to me by the Canada Parks woman at the Station exhibit and I wasn't disappointed
Great place to learn about the arctic nature, history, and life.
For a small museum in a small town, this is very complete and very well done. They have a very nice gift shop with reasonable prices as well.

There isn't a whole bunch going on in Churchill so when you see a small museum, you get excited. They have the original chair from Amundsen's ship, the Gjoa, 1st vessel to transverse the NW Passage. Ship is now in Oslo.

I admit I am not a big fan of Museums, but this was very interesting, They had a large display of tools, carvings and relics.And their gift shop had a pretty diversified selection of books, jewelry, scarves, etc.
Allow about an hour, for this fascinating little museum. Plenty to see and learn and will help you get a feel for the area and its history.
Not big, but lots of native culture to look at. The gift shop has a variety of good items. Part of the Churchill experience and free!
It is a small museum along with a shop. I really liked the history of the Eskimos. You can find great souvenirs in the shop at great prices.
The collection of Eskimo art is wonderful. The best pieces are in collection, not for sale. But display is crowded and there is only one small room
Many fine artifacts on display. They also sell local craft items, and lots of books on polar bears, and First Nation people.
We had a very interesting time at the museum. The guides are very informative and provide some info on the history of the area. It was very enjoyable.
The Eskimo Museum is a must see. The displays are amazing and it's THE best place for books, t-shirts, caps and other souvenirs. We spent 1 hour there and it was well worth it.
Interesting carvings made of bone and ivory. I also liked the historical exhibits about the First Nation peoples of the area. Great staff with lots of good stories.
Very interesting place to spend a hour or two. Staff is very approachable and informative. In the corner are a few gift-shop items to purchase and some very cool books.
The museum has an amazing number of very interesting items packed into one large room. There are a lot of narwhale tusks, a giant trilobite, kayaks and more.

The docents are very knowledgeable and there are some very nice displays. It was included as part of our itinerary and I expected something different, something a bit bigger. Their gift shop is very limited and has mostly stuff made in China. I would have loved to pick up some of the miniature bone work but they didn't have any...
The museum is well laid out with some excellent displays. It also sells souvenirs at very good prices. Well worth the time to see it.
We'll worth a visit while in Churchill. The lady in charge is very knowledgeable and helpful. We went as a group and it gave us a better insight into life way up there.
A fascinating museum, which is full of so many interesting pieces from the area. The staff have so much enthusiasm and are very helpful and informative. A place not to be missed..
Nice collection of local art and animals with a very friendly staff. Also a great place to buy local turist stuff while supporting the Museum.
Great displays, informative, lots of historical information on the northern people, wildlife, and way of life. Very friendly staff. Great prices on northern carvings for purchase.

The Eskimo Museum is a great little museum in Churchill. It costs just a donation to visit and you can check out this one room museum filled with a variety of Inuit Carvings as well as a Variety of Stuffed Arctic Animals that are humongous. There is also a great little gift shop that for me personally had the best...
Great museum of our natives contribution, plus a super gift shop. Owner was very helpful and informative about both the museum and the local history.

A great collection of artifacts and displays. It also has a very good selection of books and souvenirs. The prices for them are very fair and probably the best in town. The staff were very friendly and knowledgeable about the area and displays. A definite must see in Churchill.
While very small, this gives a wonderful view of Churchill and it's wildlife. It also has a tiny but nice gift shop with a nice section of books about the area and culture.

This museum is great! It has a very large selection of artifacts of the north. You could spend quite a while looking at everything and reading the descriptions of what everything is. The staff are very helpful and friendly, and I found this place to have some of the best souvenirs in all of Churchill. Definitely the best selection of...

I was working in Churchill, so by the time i finished, there was only 1/2 hour before the Museum closed. After seeing what the Museum had to offer, i made sure i was back for another visit! You will need a couple of hours, so many interesting displays!! I really liked their gift shop as well. Good prices.

We have been to Churchill twice now and both times we took in the Eskimo Museum. It has great souvenirs that reflect the culture in the area. It gives a lot of the history of Churchill. It has books about the area for sale. A must see.
I enjoyed reading about the various artifacts and crafts.The use of animal parts for making tools etc was pretty interesting.
Spent 3 hours checking out the exhibits and carvings. Learned so much, very interesting. Folks in the museum are very knowledgeable and helpful.

The best thing going for the Museum is the "Manager". He is a wealth of information to anyone who will ask a question on most any topic dealing with the North and the "First Peoples." No one should go to Churchill and not go to the museum.

I found the best gifts at the Eskimo Museum and for the lowest prices in town. Tons of options. The museum tour was informative and the staff knew their information. Lots of artifacts to look at! Well worth the visit.

This museum works on donations and offers one of the best insights to 'Life in the North' that I have ever seen. The staff and volunteers are knowledgeable and friendly. One of the BEST selection of 'northern books' and unique souvenirs!
Lots and lots of history, carvings, and information about the area. A great gift shop where you can find something for everyone.
This is a wonderful museum with lots of artifacts. Nice gift shop too. Some fantastic carvings. It was included with our Churchill Nature Tour.
this place is a treasure. dont miss it. check out the book selection. I have been here so many times, and I still havent seen it all.

Want to learn a little more about polar bears and life in the Northern Territories?With free admission (although contributions are welcomed) spending a few hours at the Eskimo Museum is definitely not a bad choice.Started through the hard work and dedication of the Catholic community in Churchill, the museum houses some interesting artwork and artifacts.One item I...

We were a little skittish about visiting this site at first, since I'd gotten the impression years ago that the word "Eskimo" was mostly considered a lumpish insult by First Nation peoples, but even if this is the case this museum was a delight to visit. I went back a second time and learned yet more, and took many photographs...

This is a charming, small museum and on the top of the list of admittedly a small list of things to see in Churchill. The art and historical items are quite important and the gift shop is the place to go for purchases from art to postcards. We purchased a lovely, hand-carved polar bear, certified as the work of a...
Well organized-- informed staff- picture taking allowed-great souvenirs. Many Eskimo artifacts on display each one more interesting than the next.
There were quite a few things to see here including the biggest trilobite ever found. There were also interesting books and dvd's that could be purchased.
Very interesting place you will need to give yourself about 2/3 hours to do it justice there is also some souvenirs for sale there

Well worth going to see how the Inuit people lived and understand their culture. Great displays and recorded information. Only place that sell bears that look like Polar Bears all other places just have white teddy bears
A real find - all sorts of weird and wonderful things - definitely worth a visit if you get a chance.
it was free and very thorough. It has a large collection of historical art sculpture. Only place in town were I could find a window sticker. Also a good place to buy soviernors.

One of the best collections of indigenous art in the Northern part of Canada, all gathered in one large room and curated by friendly people. Allow a little longer than you would expect, since you're certain to be drawn in to ever expanding collection.

My visit started with an interesting talk from the curator who gave background information on the museum. I was then able to explore the exhibits myself and ask questions of the staff who were on hand. There are a lot of very interesting exhibits spanning millions of years, from the largest trilobite fossil right up to modern day sculptures.The...

This museum was on my to do list, but I didn't get to it until my last hours in Churchill. This is a great place to study the history of the different natives as well as a good spot to pick up unique gifts.
A must see ! Should be mandatory to learn about the location and culture. Great exhibit! Plus its free!
Had a free talk from the curator which was a little long.Many interesting exhibits of wildlife an eskimo culture.
Wonderful museum in an out-of-the-way place. I couldn't believe the depth of their exhibits and the artifacts on display. Wonderful gift shop, too! Profits go back into the museum.
It's free, but do leave a donation. Nice artifacts. You can kill an hour here when on downtown between tundra tours.
A great little museum in the town of Churchill. Lots of carvings and stories from the local Inuit. An hour well spent.
Take the time to listen to the audio recordings that give you great information about the fascinating Inuit displays. Free entrance is well worth a donation.

Important to visit,because you will have abetter understanding of the area.Very good guidance, informative with competence.the shop has a good variation of books .the art of the Inuit and the way of their living is shown excellent. The task of walrus impressed me especially..The vist of this museum is a must Ndola everybody should take the time for...

Housed in the building are stuffed animals and artifacts and crafts of the First Nation people who live around Churchill. You can get a good idea of the size and power of a polar bear while looking at the stuffed bear in the exhibit. The museum curators are extremely knowledgable about the displays.

One room museum has myriad artifacts from various Northern cultures, although mostly carvings and sculptures. Most reflect aspects of daily living and are made from a variety of materials. Nice narrative available at many cases (although only about half were operational when we were there). Emphasis on the Canadian Inuit, but lots of similarities with peoples of Alaska and British...
This place is free so you can't knock it. It's one of the only things to do in the town of churchill. A few stuffed wild animals and lots of Inuit art work. Definitely worth a visit and free

Small but it is packed with artifacts, stories, and arts from local natives. We spent 1 hour, but it was not enough. So, we went back after lunch time (closes 12 to 13 fro lunch). Beautiful arts and carvings.

This museum took me a bit by surprise. I was expecting more about the history and culture of the Inuit people and the area around Churchill, but for the most part it's just a collection of Inuit art. Mostly sculptures. Which is fine if that's what you're expecting, but I was hoping for a wider view of the North. Having...
We spent several hours in this small museum because there are so many fascinating exhibits, all with stories behind them.

Our nature tour arranged for us to visit – I was not excited to go. BUT – and WOW– what a place – incredible artifacts and history of the people of which I knew little. I was fascinated and stayed as long as I could. Do visit – it is a real cultural/educational/enlightening experience. Don’s miss it if in Churchill
Amazing artifacts and sculptures. Gives a person a real feeling of the history of the Northern people.

We had several hours to explore Churchill after our trip to Seal River Heritage Lodge. This museum is jam-packed full of artefacts and information, and the staff hugely friendly and knowledgeable. A "must see"!
Plenty of native art art artefacts. A good place to spend an hour in a very small town. Not to miss in Churchill.
Art tells a story and I learned a lot about the north by looking at the collection. Great shopping in the gift shop!

Unique displays of the inuit history and culture of the town and wildlife. A must when visiting Churchill. The people at the Museum are very friendly and will answer any questions. The gift shop also has some very interesting books.
...I was in Chruchill to be outside.There is a narwal tusk and a stuffed walrus.Not much else to say

I have been a Churchill resident for just over 2 years now and I am astonished every time I step foot in the Eskimo Museum. Undoubtedly one of the best Northern art collection out there and of unthinkable cultural value. The head of the museum is a walking library, passionate in her work and her latest book is a must...

If you rush through the museum it is just a amall town museum. if you take your time and really look it is amazing. Every showcase needs to be pondered over. Fantastic amount of history in this building.
Excellent display of artifacts; host was extremely helpful, gift shop excellent
comprehensive and informative helpful staff and an educational experience
Enjoyed spending the afternoon at the Eskimo Museum. Lots of artifacts to see. Staff at the museum were friendly and informed. It was off season so museum was only open in the afternoon.

As Churchill is a baron town, meaning you can only fly, use the train or take a boat. There are about 500 people who live there - most being Eskimos. The other people who have come to study.You learn about them and how they survive the winters.
The Eskimo Museum has a wonderful collection of Inuit art. There are also exhibits of wildlife and a small gift shop. It is well worth a visit while you are in Churchill.
Great place to learn about the area and unique culture.
If you are really interested in local culture this is a must. You could easily spend several hours here.The staff are devoted and incredibly knowledgable.
The museum gives a beautiful overview of known history of the region as well as offering books and items for continued learning. A must seee

Leave enough time to look at the native carvings and artwork. This tiny museum has an excellent gift shop, several preserved and mounted mammals and birds, and an extensive collection of artifacts. It is a "must see" attraction.
The is an amazing museum. We did not have enough time to savor all carvings and the stories they told.

This was an unexpected plus on our visit to Churchill with Natural Habitat. We went back twice to enjoy the small but excellent collection. The staff was very helpful and the small shop had excellent crafts. If in Churchill this is a must see.
Not much to do in town when not out on tour but this museum was an interesting diversion.
I loved all teh historical photos and artifacts and stuffed animals. I bought a few books and postcards.
Quite small but full of fascinating things. Had an informal guided tour from a very helpful and knowledgeable lady. Also has good selection of gifts, reasonably priced
I loved all the artifacts but it might have been nice to have someone who could give the whole thing more depth. If you like self guided it was perfect.
Beautiful gifts and bookd for sale here - much nicer than many of the "gift shops" and the prices are sometimes lower too!
HIstorical information and native Canadian artifacts.
Loved it. Recommended to all visitors in Churchill.
Interesting display and and a very well stocked gift shop.

This museum is only one room, but it is a very large room. The cases line the walls and are packed full of interesting things. There are phones to pick up at the cases if you want to listen to an explanation. It is an impressive collection for the remote location of Churchill. There are also several taxidermied animals (polar...

This little museum was founded by the Anglican church, not by the native Inuits, but nonetheless treatment of the subject matter is highly respectful and the collection of artifacts is quite lovely. It also has a nice little gift shop with by far the best prices, especially for t-shirts, in town.
If you only have a short time in Churchill spend some time at the Eskimo Museum. They have a wonderful collection of carvings and a nice little shop with not-so-tacky souvenirs.
Well displayed too. Small place but the town is small and not too many visitors

To see artifacts from the history of the Hudson Bay and Arctic peoples, drop into this largeone-room exhibit which has a polar bear and a musk-ox on display. Great, genuine giftshop. By donation. Staff are knowledgeable. Do ask them questions.

Very interesting place. I recommend talking to the curator as she has been there several years. The hours are restricted so check them out before you walk over there. The books are an amazing variety and the inuit sculpture prices are very reasonable, more so than some other shops. A good place to go shopping for friends and loved ones....
a very good sample of inuit lifstyles and culture. Very much enjoyed our visit. There is more inside than it looks from the outside.

The Eskimo Museum in Churchill is a small building stuffed full of cultural artifacts and natural history exhibits relating to the Inuit culture. It also has a small gift shop with nice (not too touristy) souvenirs, clothing, postcards, and books.The wildlife exhibits contain both photos (lots of fish photos) and actual stuffed animals, including walrus, wolf, caribou, birds, and...

We just returned from a week at the Seal River Heritage Lodge where we got in zodiac boats and swam with Beluga whales, saw polar bears from a safe distance out in the wild and then spent our last day in Churchill. Do not miss visiting the Eskimo Museum in Churchill. The town is small and you can easily walk...

The Eskimo Museum is located on one of the side streets of Churchill. The outside of the building is not impressive. But step in inside and be prepared for a surprise. The history, life and times of the Eskimoes and the Inuit are told through the art work and the tools used by these native people. There are excellent displays...
